questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic complaining of continuous leakage of urine from her vagina for the past 3 months since her last delivery. She is not able to hold urine. She reports having experienced prolonged & obstructed labor during her last delivery. On examination, her thighs and vulva were excoriated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Bladder Fistula

Ureteric Fistula

 

 

Aetiology

Mostly obstetric causes

  • Prolonged labour
  • vaginal caesarean section.
  • sling operations
  • hysterectomy

Following

surgical procedures i.e. LSCS

 

Clinical

Continuous dribbling of

urine - no micturition

Continuous dribbling

of urine but can

also, micturate

 

Methylene swab

test

Swab stains with

methylene blue

Swab stains with

urine but not with

methylene blue

Bladder

Ureter

Urethra
  • Vesicovaginal fistula
  • Vesicocervical fistula
  • Vesicouterine fistula
  • Ureterovaginal fistula
  • Ureteroabdominal fistula
  • Urethrovaginal fistula

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida woman has been in labor for the past 20 hours with little progress despite strong contractions. Despite attempts at assisted vaginal delivery, the labor is not progressing. Because of obstructed labor, an emergency cesarean section is performed. Postoperatively, the patient complains of continuous leakage of fluid from her vagina and inability to hold urine. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Conservative

Surgical
  • Genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • In 10 percent of cases, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small.




 

Transvaginal Repair:

  • This approach involves accessing the fistula through the vaginal wall.
  • It is suitable for smaller fistulas and those located in favorable positions that allow for direct access and closure.

Transabdominal Repair:

  • Larger or more complex fistulas may require an abdominal approach.
  • This can be done via laparotomy (open surgery) or laparoscopy (minimally invasive surgery).
  • Laparoscopy is preferred when feasible as it offers faster recovery and reduced postoperative complications.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a complaint of continuous urinary leakage that has persisted for several weeks. Her medical history is significant for a recent hysterectomy performed six weeks ago. On physical examination, there is a constant trickle of clear fluid from the vagina. Which of the following is the most appropriate test to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Cystoscopy with dye test
  • It involves inserting a dye solution (methylene blue)for confirming the diagnosis.

MRI or CT Scan
  • These imaging modalities may be used to assess complex cases or to plan surgical repair, providing detailed anatomical information.

Intravenous pyelogram (IVP)
  • (IVP) is a diagnostic imaging test that is not typically used as a primary method to diagnose vesico-vaginal fistula (VVF).

questions.text: A 29-year-old female with a history of 2 prior C-sections came to gynecology OPD with amenorrhoea and cyclic hematuria and her Urine Pregnancy Test was negative. What is the most probable diagnosis?
Which of the following is the trans-vaginal approach for the repair of vesico-vaginal fistula?
questions.explanation:
Conservative

Surgical
  • Genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • In 10 percent of cases, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small.

Transvaginal Repair/ Latzko method:

  • This approach involves accessing the fistula through the vaginal wall.
  • It is suitable for smaller fistulas and those located in favorable positions that allow for direct access and closure.

Transabdominal Repair:

  • Larger or more complex fistulas may require an abdominal approach.
  • This can be done via laparotomy or laparoscopy
  • Laparoscopy is preferred when feasible as it offers faster recovery and reduced postoperative complications.

Lash and lash surgery (option A)

This procedure is used for transvaginal approach of cervical cerclage

Delorme's operation (option B)

Used to treat rectal prolapse.

Altemeier procedure (option D)

Used for the treatment of rectal prolapse.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of urinary leakage. She reports that she leaks urine when she coughs, sneezes, or exercises. She also experiences occasional sudden urges to urinate that she cannot control, especially when she hears running water or after holding her urine for some time. Which types of urinary incontinence are likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Stress urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine with effort or physical exertion or when sneezing or coughing.

Urgency urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency or sudden, compelling desire to void that is difficult to defer.

Mixed urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine associated with urgency and with physical exertion, sneezing or coughing.

Overactive bladder

Urinary urgency, typically accompanied by frequency and nocturia, with or without urge urinary incontinence, in the absence of urinary tract infection or other obvious pathology.

Nocturnal enuresis

Involuntary loss of urine that occurs during sleep.

Functional urinary incontinence

Involuntary loss of urine that is due to cognitive, functional, or mobility impairments in the presence of an intact lower urinary tract system.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman, 6 months postpartum after her second child, presents to her obstetrician with complaints of occasional urine leakage when she sneezes or laughs. She reports these symptoms started after childbirth and have been gradually worsening. Which of the following factors is not typically associated with the condition?

A 32-year-old woman who recently gave birth to her third child via vaginal delivery presents with complaints of occasional leakage of urine when she sneezes or laughs. She reports that these symptoms started about two months after childbirth and have been gradually worsening. On examination, there is no evidence of urinary tract infection. What type of urinary incontinence is most likely affecting this patient?
questions.explanation:
Type of Incontinence

Clinical Features

Stress Incontinence
  • Leakage with physical activity (coughing, sneezing, exercise)
  • Small amounts of urine lost

Urge Incontinence
  • Sudden, intense urge to urinate followed by leakage
  • Frequent urination, including nocturia

Overflow Incontinence
  • Frequent or constant dribbling of urine
  • Weak stream, hesitancy
  • Feeling of bladder fullness, incomplete voiding

Functional Incontinence
  • Inability to reach the bathroom in time
  • Normal urinary system function

Reflex Incontinence
  • Involuntary loss of urine without warning or urge
  • Occurs at predictable intervals or situations

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who recently gave birth via vaginal delivery presents with complaints of urinary leakage when she coughs, sneezes, or exercises. She reports that these symptoms started shortly after childbirth and have been affecting her daily activities. Which investigation is not done for further evaluation of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Urine Culture (Option A)
  • Essential to rule out urinary tract infections before invasive tests.

Stress Test
  • Objective method to demonstrate stress urinary incontinence (SUI).

Q-Dip cotton Swab Test: (outdated)

  • Evaluates bladder neck mobility.
  • Positive test if swab angle increases significantly (>20°).

Marshall's and Bonney's Test: (outdated)

  • Checks for the absence of urine leakage post-bladder neck elevation.
  • Indicates potential benefit from surgical repair if negative.

Urethroscopy
  • Visualizes urethra, trigone, and bladder neck.

Cystometry

Measures bladder and urethral pressures during artificial filling to differentiate types of incontinence.

Urethrocystometry

Assesses urethral pressure dynamics, crucial for diagnosing incontinence conditions.

Uroflowmetry

Measures urine flow rate and volume, providing non-invasive data on voiding function.

Micturition Cystourethrography

Evaluates the urethrovesical angle to diagnose stress incontinence.

Uroprofilometry

Measures dynamic urethral pressures, crucial for diagnosing urethral conditions.

Ultrasonography

(Option B)

Measures bladder volume and residual urine; useful for identifying bladder wall abnormalities.

Videocystourethrography

Integrates pressure studies with video to assess lower urinary tract function.

MRI Studies

Assesses pelvic floor muscle defects; helpful for surgical planning to correct incontinence.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with no medical comorbidities complaints of involuntary leakage of urine primarily when she coughs or sneezes. She has tried Kegel exercises, lifestyle modifications, such as avoiding caffeine, and pessary but these have not significantly improved her symptoms. What would be the most appropriate next step in the management of her condition?
questions.explanation:
Type of urinary Incontinence

Stress urinary Incontinence

Urgency urinary Incontinence

Overflow Incontinence

Step 1
  • Lifestyle
  • Weight loss in obese individuals
  • Reduce fluid and caffeine intake
  • Avoiding bladder irritants (e.g., caffeine, alcohol, carbonated drinks)
  • Restrict intake of fluid to 1 liter/day

If non-obstructive pathology

  • Continuous catheter drainage
  • Intermittent self-catheterization

Step 2
  • Pelvic floor muscle training( Kegel exercises)
  • Biofeedback therapy
  • Scheduled Voiding
  • Bladder retraining
  • Scheduled voiding

If obstructive pathology

  • Alpha-blockers (tamsulosin for bladder outlet obstruction)
  • Urethroplasty for urethral strictures

Step 3

Medical Treatment

  • Estrogen
  • Sympathomimetic drugs (α-adrenergic) Imipramine

Medical Treatment

  • Anticholinergics:
  1. Oxybutynin
  2. Tolterodine
  3. Fesoterodine fumarate
  4. Darifenacin
  • Beta -3 adrenergic agonist (Mirabegron* )
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., imipramine)
  

Step 4

Devices

  • Pessary
  • Urethral Inserts

Neuromodulation

  • Sacral nerve stimulation
  • Peripheral tibial nerve stimulation

Intradetrusor botulinum toxin A injection

 

  

Step 5

Surgical Treatment

  • Colposuspension
  • Midurethral tape

Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT)

Transobturator tape (TOT)

  • Microslings
  • Bladder neck suspension
  • Bulking agents injection
  • Others

Marshall-Marchetti-Krantz (MMK)

Paravaginal repair

Surgical Treatment

  • Cystoplasty (to increase bladder capacity)
  • Urinary diversion procedures (eg. ileal conduit)

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with complaints of frequent urination, urgency, and urge incontinence, which have been worsening over the past seven months and significantly affecting her quality of life. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for the initial pharmacological management of overactive bladder in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Mechanism of action

Oxybutynin (Option A)

Tolterodine

Fesoterodine fumarate

Trospium chloride

Antimuscarinic

Darifenacin

Solifenacin

M3-selective antimuscarinic

Imipramine

Tricyclic antidepressant, anticholinergic, α-adrenergic, antihistamine

Mirabegron

β3 adrenergic agonist

References:

  • ↳ Reference:
  • ↳ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2800025/

Drug

Mechanism of action

Estrogen (useful in postmenopausal patient) (Option B)

Increase urethral blood flow and α-adrenergic receptor sensitivity

Imipramine

Tricyclic antidepressant, anticholinergic, α-adrenergic, antihistamine

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with stress urinary incontinence. Conservative treatments have not alleviated her symptoms and the decision is made to proceed with a tension-free transvaginal tape (TVT) procedure. Which specific anatomical space is the tape positioned by the surgeon in this procedure?
questions.explanation:
Procedure

Key concepts

Burch colposuspension (gold standard)

The ipsilateral iliopectineal ligament is sutured to the endopelvic fascia and/or the lateral vaginal fornix.

Tension-free vaginal tape (TVT) (option B)

Tape is passed vaginally under the midurethral and along the back of the pubic bone (retropubic space) as depicted in the figure below.

Transobturator tape (TOT) (option A)

Sling material is passed bilaterally through the obturator foramen and underneath the mid urethra.

Minimally invasive slings

"Microslings" or "minislings" are TVT and TOT modifications. The mesh does not enter through the obturator foramen or the retropubic area.

Pubovaginal sling procedures

Functions via urethra compression at the urethrovesical junction.
